meanings.definition: To cause disgust or aversion by excess
meanings.sent1: Eating too much candy can cloy the taste buds.
meanings.sent2: The sweetness of the dessert began to cloy after a few bites.
meanings.sent3: The endless loop of the same song started to cloy on my ears.
meanings.sent4: The constant praise began to cloy like a heavy perfume in the room.
meanings.sent5: The smell of the flowers was so strong it seemed to cloy the air itself.

meanings.definition: To become wearisome or distasteful through excess
meanings.sent1: The repetitive tasks began to cloy on her mind.
meanings.sent2: The movie's predictable plot started to cloy on the audience.
meanings.sent3: The joke was funny at first, but now it's starting to cloy on me.
meanings.sent4: The monotonous routine began to cloy on his spirit like a heavy weight.
meanings.sent5: The taste of the medicine was so bitter it seemed to cloy in his mouth.
